key_insight: Author Correction: The corrected study presents a hybrid approach that combines coding theory and deep learning to make DNA-based data storage more scalable and robust to biochemical errors and sequencing noise.
problem_solved: Overcomes key practical barriers to DNA archival storage — high error rates, biochemical sequence constraints, and limited scalability of prior encoding/decoding pipelines that prevented reliable large-scale use.
method: Use coding-theory constructions tailored to DNA sequence constraints to increase error tolerance and storage density.
Apply deep learning models for noisy-read denoising and improved decoding of sequencing output, complementing classical error-correction.
Integrate and benchmark an end-to-end encoding → synthesis → sequencing → decoding pipeline under realistic error models (as corrected in this Author Correction).
impact: Makes DNA storage more viable for long-term, high-density archival of large datasets and ML models by reducing data-loss risk and improving retrieval accuracy; demonstrates a template for combining algorithmic codes with learned decoders for other noisy channels.
visual_elements: Pipeline flowchart: Encoding (codes) → DNA synthesis → Sequencing → Deep-learning-assisted decoding
Illustration showing complementary roles: error-correcting codes (symbolic blocks) + neural network (probabilistic denoising)
Comparison bar chart: reliability / error rate / throughput before vs. after applying the hybrid method
Icons: DNA strand, neural network, shield (robustness), stacked disks (storage) to encode concepts at a glance
paper_title: Author Correction: Scalable and robust DNA-based storage via coding theory and deep learning
paper_authors: Daniella Bar-Lev, Itai Orr, Omer Sabary, Tuvi Etzion, Eitan Yaakobi
